dt: {bc}moving or capable of moving with great speed
{bc}occurring suddenly or within a very short time

pt: {sc}fast{/sc} {sc}rapid{/sc} {sc}swift{/sc} {sc}fleet{/sc} {sc}quick{/sc} {sc}speedy{/sc} {sc}hasty{/sc} {sc}expeditious{/sc} mean moving, proceeding, or acting with celerity. {sc}fast{/sc} and {sc}rapid{/sc} are very close in meaning, but {sc}fast{/sc} applies particularly to the thing that moves
{sc}swift{/sc} suggests great rapidity coupled with ease of movement.

pt.t: returned the ball with one {it}swift{/it} stroke

pt: {sc}fleet{/sc} adds the implication of lightness and nimbleness.
{sc}quick{/sc} suggests promptness and the taking of little time.
and may also suggest unusual velocity. {sc}hasty{/sc} suggests hurry and precipitousness and often connotes carelessness.
{sc}expeditious{/sc} suggests efficiency together with rapidity of accomplishment.

et: Middle English, from Old English; akin to Old English {it}swīfan{/it} to revolve {ma}{mat|swivel|}{/ma}
shortdef: moving or capable of moving with great speed
occurring suddenly or within a very short time

dt: {bc}any of several lizards (especially of the genus {it}Sceloporus{/it}) that run {a_link|swiftly}
{bc}a reel for winding yarn or thread
{bc}any of numerous small plainly colored birds (family Apodidae) that are related to the hummingbirds but superficially much resemble swallows

shortdef: any of several lizards (especially of the genus Sceloporus) that run swiftly
a reel for winding yarn or thread
any of numerous small plainly colored birds (family Apodidae) that are related to the hummingbirds but superficially much resemble swallows

dt: {bc}a small fox ({it}Vulpes velox{/it}) with large ears that occurs on the plains of western North America

shortdef: a small fox (Vulpes velox) with large ears that occurs on the plains of western North America

dt: {bc}a small sooty-gray swift ({it}Chaetura pelagica{/it}) with long narrow wings that often builds its nest inside an unused chimney

shortdef: a small sooty-gray swift (Chaetura pelagica) with long narrow wings that often builds its nest inside an unused chimney —called also chimney swallow
